vocabulary.example: theater [n] - a show with actors acting on stage in a play
comedy [n] - a type of show with the purpose of being funny
a festival [n] - a large celebration in a town or city
royal [adj] - related to kings and queens
volcanic rock [n] - rock that comes from cooled lava (from volcanoes)
name (s/t) after (s/o) [phv] - give something the same name as a person to honor that person
a Great Hall [n] - a large open room in a castle
defenses [n] - buildings and structures built to protect a castle
a battle [n] - a conflict, part of a war
bonny [adj] - pretty, nice (ScE) She is a bonny lass. = (AmE) She is pretty/nice girl.
a tourist attraction [n] - a place for tourists

questions.question: Edinburgh has a population of six million.
There is a festival in Edinburgh every August.
The Royal Mile is about 1.6 km long.
Edinburgh Castle was first built in 1130.
The chapel in Edinburgh Castle was named after King David the First.
The castle became the home of the King of England in the 15th century.
King James the 4th built the Great Hall.
Scotland became part of the United Kingdom in the 16th century.
Prince Charles Edward Stewart tried to capture Edinburgh Castle.
Edinburgh Castle is used as a prison today.
About 1 250 000 people visit the castle every year.
The soldiers at Edinburgh Castle fire a gun every day at 11 o'clock.

grammar.explanation: Choose the word that connects the ideas in the sentence. Use words like: is, live, visit, start, finish, build, name, become, was, come, fire. Some boxes will be empty.

transcript.full:
Edinburgh is the capital city of Scotland. It is a very beautiful old city. About four hundred thousand people live in the city, and six million people visit every year.

Every year in August, there's a festival in the city with a lot of theater, music, dance, and comedy.

The original city was built on the Royal Mile. This is a street in Edinburgh's Old Town. The Royal Mile is about 1.6 km long. It starts at Holyrood Palace and finishes at Edinburgh Castle. It is called the Royal Mile because it connects two royal homes.

The castle is nearly a thousand years old. It stands on an enormous piece of volcanic rock, and it looks down on the rest of the city.

King David the First of Scotland was the first king who built on the rock in about 1130.

He built this chapel and named it Queen Mary's Chapel after his mother.

For the next three hundred years, the castle was at the center of wars between England and Scotland.

In the 15th century, the castle became the home of the King of Scotland. Each new king added to the castle.

In 1511, James the Fourth built the Great Hall.

In the 16th century, James the Sixth added extra defenses to the castle entrance.

In the 18th century, Scotland officially became part of the United Kingdom.

The last battle at the castle was in 1745 when Prince Charles Edward Stewart, who was nicknamed 'Bonny Prince Charley', tried to capture the castle.

In the early 19th century, the castle was a prison, but it is now a tourist attraction.

About one and a quarter million people visit the castle every year. They come to see the buildings and to hear the stories.

They also come to see and hear the one o'clock gun. Soldiers fire this every day at exactly one o'clock.

But they really come for the views of the city of Edinburgh.
